importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: Founded in 2013, the New Georgia Project was established to register and mobilize nonwhite and young voters, marking the beginning of a significant Democratic voter organizing effort in Georgia.
Stacey Abrams narrowly lost the governor’s race to Brian Kemp in 2018, signaling a pivotal moment where Democratic voter organizing efforts faced a political setback despite high turnout.

The Democratic Party made a significant gain in Georgia in 2020, with Joe Biden winning the presidential race and Democrats winning Senate seats, demonstrating the effectiveness of the New Georgia Project’s outreach model.

The 2021 Senate runoff election saw Raphael Warnock and Jon Ossoff elected, shifting control of the U.S. Senate to Democrats and affirming the impact of the New Georgia Project’s voter mobilization strategy.
Despite Abrams outraising Kemp in 2022, the Democratic candidate lost the governor’s race by a wider margin, indicating a challenge to the sustainability of voter organizing efforts.

In 2024, Republican turnout surged significantly under Trump, leading to a loss of Democratic momentum despite Kamala Harris winning more votes, highlighting the broader challenges in Democratic electoral strategy.

The closure of the New Georgia Project and its Action Fund on October 16, 2025, marks a turning point in Democratic organizing in Georgia, raising questions about long-term viability of Abrams’ model.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The period from 2013 to 2025 represents the lifespan of the New Georgia Project and its associated organizations, during which they were central to Democratic voter mobilization in Georgia.

keyTakeAways: The New Georgia Project and its Action Fund, founded by Stacey Abrams in 2013, were instrumental in registering and mobilizing nonwhite and young voters in Georgia, contributing to Democratic gains in 2020 and 2021.

Despite early success, the organizations faced legal challenges, including a record $300,000 fine from the Georgia Ethics Commission in 2018 for illegal campaign activities, which damaged their credibility and funding.
The closure of the groups in 2025 signals a decline in Democratic organizing capacity in Georgia, raising concerns about whether Abrams’ model of grassroots, progressive outreach can be sustained.

The loss of these organizations comes as Democrats prepare for key elections in 2026, including Sen. Jon Ossoff’s reelection and a gubernatorial race, underscoring the strategic vulnerability of the Democratic Party in Georgia.
Organizers report that the groups knocked on 4 million doors in 2020 and were a major force in progressive politics, with their door-knocking model being seen as unmatched in outreach and engagement.

namedEntities.name: Stacey Abrams
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Democratic politician and founder of the New Georgia Project and its Action Fund; key figure in Georgia political organizing
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: She founded the voter turnout groups that became central to Democratic organizing in Georgia, and their closure raises questions about the sustainability of her strategy.

namedEntities.name: New Georgia Project
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A nonpartisan voter registration and turnout group founded by Stacey Abrams in 2013 to mobilize nonwhite and young voters
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It was a major force in Democratic voter outreach, contributing to Senate victories in 2021 and helping shift political dynamics in Georgia.

namedEntities.name: New Georgia Project Action Fund
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Affiliated fundraising arm of the New Georgia Project, focused on campaign finance and voter mobilization
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It supported the broader voter organizing mission and faced legal penalties and financial decline, leading to its closure.

namedEntities.name: Fair Fight
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Another voter organizing group founded by Stacey Abrams, which also faced legal losses and operational challenges
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The closure of both the New Georgia Project and Fair Fight raises broader concerns about the long-term sustainability of Abrams’ organizing model.

namedEntities.name: Brian Kemp
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Republican governor of Georgia, opponent of Stacey Abrams in multiple elections
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He represents the entrenched Republican political power in Georgia, which the New Georgia Project sought to challenge and overcome.

namedEntities.name: Joe Biden
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: President of the United States in 2020, who won Georgia’s presidential vote
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: His victory in Georgia in 2020 was a key outcome of the New Georgia Project’s voter mobilization efforts.

namedEntities.name: Raphael Warnock
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Democratic U.S. Senator from Georgia, elected in 2021 and reelected in 2024
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He was elected as a result of the New Georgia Project’s outreach and represents a shift in Georgia’s political balance.

namedEntities.name: Jon Ossoff
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Democratic U.S. Senator from Georgia, seeking reelection in 2026
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: His upcoming reelection campaign occurs in a context of declining Democratic organizing capacity, making the closure of the New Georgia Project particularly significant.

namedEntities.name: Kamala Harris
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Vice President of the United States in 2024, who won more Democratic votes than Biden in Georgia
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Her performance in 2024 revealed continued challenges in Democratic turnout despite gains in vote share, highlighting the difficulty of sustaining momentum.

namedEntities.name: Georgia Ethics Commission
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: State body that enforced campaign finance laws and levied a $300,000 fine on the New Georgia Project in 2018
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The fine and legal penalties significantly damaged the organizations’ credibility and funding, contributing to their eventual closure.

namedEntities.name: Rev. James Woodall
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Chair of the board of the New Georgia Project Action Fund
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He provided leadership during the closure and expressed the ongoing urgency of progressive political work.

namedEntities.name: Stephanie Jackson Ali
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Former policy director of the New Georgia Project
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: She provided insider perspective on the scale and impact of the organization’s outreach and expressed sorrow over its decline.

namedEntities.name: Georgia
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: U.S. state where the organizations operated and where political dynamics are central to the article
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The state's political landscape — with deep-rooted Republican dominance and a history of Democratic setbacks — is central to understanding the significance of the group’s closure.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Two voter turnout organizations in Georgia, the New Georgia Project and its affiliated Action Fund, founded by Democrat Stacey Abrams in 2013, have announced their closure. The groups were central to mobilizing nonwhite and young voters, contributing to Democratic victories in the 2020 presidential election and the 2021 Senate runoffs. Despite early success, they faced significant legal challenges, including a record $300,000 fine from the Georgia Ethics Commission in 2018 for illegal campaign activities and improper fundraising, and a subsequent decline in funding and staff. Organizers reported knocking on 4 million doors in 2020 and praised the outreach as unmatched in progressive politics. The closure, along with legal losses at Fair Fight, raises urgent questions about the sustainability of Abrams’ voter organizing model in Georgia, especially as Democrats prepare for key elections in 2026, including Sen. Jon Ossoff’s re-election and a gubernatorial race. The decline signals a broader challenge in maintaining Democratic grassroots momentum in a state where Republicans have historically held dominant power.
title: Georgia voter turnout groups founded by Stacey Abrams are closing
